title: Terminator: Dark Fate review: James Cameron has effectively written the same story all over again
text:
Terminator: Dark Fate Cert: 15, 2hrs 8mins

Rating:

Linda Hamilton is only 63, but in Hollywood years, especially female action-hero Hollywood years – surely the most unforgiving kind – that makes the original Terminator star about 157.

But in the period of conspicuous and deliberate change that the film industry is currently engaged in, of fairer representation and remuneration regardless of age, gender or ethnicity, it also now makes her very employable Hollywood royalty too.

So while it’s lovely to catch our first glimpse of her back as Sarah Connor in Terminator: Dark Fate – emerging from a rusting pick-up with scowl, tight vest, machine gun, the Sarah Connor we know and love – it’s also totally unsurprising: this is very much a Terminator film for these changing times.

So while it’s lovely to catch our first glimpse of Sarah Connor in Terminator: Dark Fate, it’s also totally unsurprising: this is very much a Terminator film for these changing times

With the new film being released 35 years after the iconic original, Hamilton is no token female presence this time around. There’s also a character who we initially take to be the first female terminator (actually an ‘augmented’ super-soldier) and a young, female Mexican factory worker whose survival soon turns out to be crucial to the entire human race.

But even before we’ve had time to think, ‘Hmm, that sounds familiar’, we’re hit with another example of fast-changing times. When Grace – said super-soldier, played by the Canadian Mackenzie Davis – first arrives, she continues the long-standing, time-travelling terminator tradition of arriving stark naked.

There was a time when the fight that results, before she’s stolen any clothes, would have aroused considerable interest in adolescent males of all ages. Now director Tim Miller, of Deadpool fame, delivers a sequence that wouldn’t make a prim maiden aunt blush.

Linda Hamilton is only 63, but in Hollywood years, especially female action-hero Hollywood years – surely the most unforgiving kind – that makes the original Terminator star about 157

There are two other important things you need to know. First is that while this is the sixth Terminator film to be made, in terms of franchise chronology it’s actually a sequel to the excellent, Oscar-winning Terminator 2: Judgment Day.

And second is that good ol’ Arnie is back once again, digitally but briefly de-aged, as the new film loses no time in putting the central story of the first two films well and truly behind us.

‘Skynet? What’s Skynet?’ asks a puzzled visitor from the future, clearly knowing nothing of the computer defence system that became self-aware and unleashed nuclear Armageddon when it perceived the human race as a threat.

Well, that’s the first two films out of the way.

Good ol’ Arnie (above with Gabriel Luna) is back once again as the new film loses no time in putting the central story of the first two films well and truly behind us

There’s quite a lot to enjoy here as original director James Cameron returns to the franchise that launched his fine film-making career, this time as producer and co-writer.

Our first proper glimpses of Hamilton and Schwarzenegger feel like proper moments of film history.

There are some touches of humour too, with Arnie’s ageing terminator now passing himself off as human and working in soft furnishings, while Hamilton’s Connor has lost none of her attitude, as becomes clear when Grace decides it’s time for the feisty trio to move from Mexico to Texas.

IT'S A FACT OJ Simpson was considered for The Terminator but the producers feared he was 'too nice' to be taken seriously as a killer.

‘You want to try and cross the border with an undocumented Mexican national and a woman who had her own episode of America’s Most Wanted?’ asks Sarah dryly.

But none of this is quite enough to make a decently work-a-day Terminator film into a great one. Surprisingly, given that Cameron is involved, some of the visual effects aren’t that convincing.

Then there’s the undeniable fact that neither Davis, as Grace, nor the Colombian actress Natalia Reyes, who plays Mexican Dani, exactly set the screen alight. I even found myself slightly wearying of the Terminator’s endless ability to repair itself.

The main problem, however, is the sheer familiarity of the story. For while there’s a certain pleasure in recognising some of the iconography of the first two films – the sunglasses, the guns, a terminator dressed as a policeman – it’s disappointing to find that Cameron and his writing team have effectively written the same story all over again.

Which, when Arnie said, ‘I’ll be back’, is probably not quite what he had in mind. Shame.

ALSO OUT THIS WEEK

Black And Blue (15)

Rating:

There’s no doubt this grittily urban police thriller is often more style than substance, but equally there’s no doubt it packs a proper punch too, tapping into the widely held belief that American police departments are racist.

So when Alicia West, a rookie black officer – played pretty well by Naomie Harris – witnesses her white superiors executing three black drug-dealers, she’s in a whole heap of nasty trouble.

Her corrupt white colleagues want her dead, and so do the black drugs gangs, who believe she’s responsible for the killing. Thank goodness she’s got the video evidence on her body-cam…

Some of the plotting is as clunky as the characterisation is clichéd – not only is Alicia a resourceful Afghanistan veteran but she came from the same impoverished streets in New Orleans she now patrols – but tension levels are well maintained and the film’s powerful point is effectively made.

The Addams Family (PG)

Rating:

I’ve never really warmed to the Addams family, and this cartoon take on the familiar ghoulish story proves no different, despite a voice cast led by Charlize Theron and Oscar Isaac.

Jokes fall horribly flat and the story proves decidedly thin, as Morticia (Theron), Gomez (Isaac) and the rest of the gang move into a new home only to incur the displeasure of nosey neighbour and local gossip Margaux (Allison Janney).

Jokes fall horribly flat and the story proves decidedly thin, as Morticia (Charlize Theron), Gomez (Oscar Isaac) and the rest of the gang move into a new home

It’s clearly aimed mainly at children, and Chloë Grace Moretz probably has the most fun as family goth Wednesday, who not only gets to go to junior high school but also discovers the colour pink. Not nearly as funny as it sounds.

The Beach Bum (18)

Rating:

It’s difficult to know who is more indulged here, Matthew McConaughey, who plays the title character (a mumbling, drugs- and alcohol-fuelled beat-poet known as Moondog), or director and art-house favourite Harmony Korine, who has assembled a starry cast despite not having made a decent film for years.

A game Isla Fisher is briefly good fun as Moondog’s highly sexed wife but then the film falls apart. Look out for Zac Efron and Jonah Hill in supporting roles, both presumably hoping nobody will recognise them.
